title: ISic003013. Statue of Demeter with inscribed base
body:
1προστά τ̣ [αι] Δ̣ά̣μ̣α̣τ̣ρος
2Γάϊος Ὀρκήιος Γαίου
3Γάϊος Σολπίκιος Γαίου
4Λεύκιος Καύλιος Λευκίου
5Χαιρή̣τιος Χαιρητίου
6Λύκων Νύμφωνος

1ΠΡΟΣΤΑ.[..].....ΡΟΣ
2ΓΑΙΟΣΟΡΚΗΙΟΣΓΑΙΟΥ
3ΓΑΙΟΣΣΟΛΠΙΚΙΟΣΓΑΙΟΥ
4ΛΕΥΚΙΟΣΚΑΥΛΙΟΣΛΕΥΚΙΟΥ
5ΧΑΙΡ.ΤΙΟΣΧΑΙΡΗΤΙΟΥ
6ΛΥΚΩΝΝΥΜΦΩΝΟΣ

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

English translation

The 'prostatai' of Demeter: Gaios Orkeios, son of Gaios; Gaios Solpikios, son of Gaios; Leukios Kaulios, son of Leukios; Chairetios son of Chairetios; Lykon son of Nymphon

commentary

The statue is one of three found together close to the coast at Contrada Borgelusa di Avola, in the immediate vicinity of the site of a first-century BC Roman villa (which had an earlier Hellenistic building underneath). The other two statues are Kore and a youthful Herakles. Demeter holds a huge torch in her right hand and piglet in left. The inscription lists five prostatai (guardians of the shrine)of Damater (Demeter). The first three names are Latin / Roman: Gaius Orceius, Gaius Sulpicius, and Lucius Caulius. Gentili (1954) records the discovery; a Roman villa was subsequently excavated in the immediate vicinity. Manganaro (2009) is the most recent discussion, dating the statue to the second century BC.

bibliography

    34.0981 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000796 Gentili 1954 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001958 Manganaro 1977 159 ph https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001440 Bacci 1984-1985 713 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002175 Manganaro 2001 86 no.V https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001806 Manganaro 2009 114 ph https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001796
Licensed under a Creative Commons-Attribution 4.0 licence.
